author: ctjlewis
content:
When you *send* a transaction, you‚Äôre paying the base fee which is estimated based on network congestion. Everyone will pay the same base fee for the current block, plus a tip.

When the block is *mined*, we know how everybody bid, in terms of tips, and transactions could be refunded a share of the ‚Äúcongestion premium‚Äù in proportion to their miner tips. **In this way, transactions will not share equally in the base fee after the block is mined, though they have to pay the same amount up front.**

Consider a one-transaction block: They will pay no base fee (only tip) after the tx is settled despite paying it when they sent it. For a 2-tx block, both bidding equal tips, they also pay no base fee after the block is mined, since the refund is split evenly between them. If they paid the base fee and bid tips of 0.01 ETH and 0.02 ETH, then the higher tipper will be refunded 2/3 of the total base fees and the other 1/3, since their tip was 2x more than the other. And so on.

Currently, to transact, you pay the premium plus a tip and the premium goes right into the black hole. It seems like there could be a way to use the information learned *after the auction settles* (at the time of block proposal) to refund base fees in a way that reduces deadweight loss on users.

My understanding is that this is a choice between subsidizing a public service or driving deflationary monetary policy. Someone wanting to interact with a Web3 service wants to do that at that moment‚Äîbuy an ENS name or something‚Äînot hold Ether and sleep soundly dreaming of market capitalization. I think it‚Äôs politically infeasible to not burn some amount of the base fee, but trying to think outside of the box here regarding fee markets.

author: ctjlewis
content:
Like I said, this is not a complete idea at all, but I think there‚Äôs utility in it somewhere.

Going back to the quadratic refund concept, that is just a way to, when the block is mined, look at the distribution of tips, and subsidize the smaller ones. If the whole distribution moves up, it doesn‚Äôt change‚Äîbut smaller transactions in a block would share less of a burden regarding congestion.

It might be that *gas used*, actual drag on the network, is a better metric to think about this in the context of. There, if your transaction is lightweight compared to others in the block, you get refunded a larger share of the base fee; computationally intensive (high-gas) txs would simply not be subsidized (but no penalty).

author: ctjlewis
content:
My point is that, at this specific moment and many times over the last few years as we all know, even the smallest transactions need to be sent with fees that amount to the monthly income of people in dozens of countries (several hundred USD) in order to get included in a block during periods of high congestion. The vast majority of people cannot afford to transact on the network right now, and I am trying to understand what can be done about it. It strikes me as a tragedy of the commons problem where the issue is not computational resources, but the result of people having to outbid each other for access to the network, and so I'm wondering if quadratic base fee refunds could be a way to ease the burden on "smaller" (do not know by what metric) txs.

author: ctjlewis
content:
And I'm sorry if I'm not being clear, I'm trying my best here, will try to do a longer-form write-up, and give a lazy example here.

Let's look at block #13518467, containing 3 transactions. ~0.0475 ETH paid in gas, ~0.0396 ETH in base fees burnt, ~0.007 ETH went to miners as tips after the burn.

**If the burnt fees had been quadratically refunded to the lowest-gas transactions,** the gas paid would've been only the ~0.007 ETH in total vs 0.0475 ETH after "settling" (being mined), with the different transactions being refunded a fraction of their base fee according to their relative gas consumption. A large portion of the lowest gas transaction's (0xdb595d...af5fff) total base fees of ~0.0071 ETH would have been refunded compared to the largest gas transaction's (0x161e72...383414) total base fees of 0.0179 ETH (which would have seen, under this framework, exponentially less susbidy).

And again this "refund" is coming from the fees which are currently now burnt. In reality I don't think it's politically feasible to not burn *any* of the base fee, but burning 100% of it seems counterproductive in terms of keeping the network affordable for non-congesting transactions in times of high *average* congestion.

author: barnabemonnot
content:
I think the point here is that if it's $2 cheaper for everyone to send transactions, then at equilibrium basefee will simply be $2 higher. You can adjust the rebate slope such that different users get different rebates and it might give you a slightly different result, but the point will still be that basefee will converge to the effective value of the 15 million-th unit of gas demanded, where the effective value is (user value + expected rebate - priority fee)

there are interesting links between 1559 and congestion however, some I looked at here https://barnabe.substack.com/p/congestion-control-and-eip1559 congestion is sort of quadratic in nature: when there is one extra user that joins, it adds 1 unit of "stress" to every other user in the system, so if you have n users, roughly congestion looks like n^2 (for linear congestion functions). but the pricing internalises this pressure, in a sense you can see the included users as paying roughly the "damage" incurred by the next non-included user (that value of the 15 million-th gas unit). It does currently internalise it in a proportional (not equal) way between small and large transactions, but the question to ask should be "does internalising it in a more-than-proportional way encourage reduced gas footprint?" there is already an incentive to have the smallest possible gas footprint, since the pricing is linear (per gas unit), so you would have to show why making that incentive quadratic, at the cost of more complex pricing (current oracles don't rely on the transaction size for instance), makes us better reach the outcome of gas efficiency
